theoryText: Usopp is uniquely suited to fight Perona not just because he discovers her physical body's location, but because his inherently negative personality makes him immune to her Negative Hollow attack. Since Usopp already possesses such a low opinion of himself and is naturally pessimistic, Perona's depression-inducing ghosts have no effect on him. This makes Usopp her only natural enemy among the Straw Hats, as he cannot be emotionally incapacitated by her most powerful ability.
supportingEvidence: Usopp's character is established as cowardly and self-deprecating throughout the series
Episode 359 shows Usopp being unaffected by Negative Hollows
Episode 360 demonstrates that Perona must rely on other abilities against Usopp
This personality trait becomes crucial to the Straw Hats' victory at Thriller Bark

theoryTitle: Perona's Astral Projection Weakness Was Foreshadowed
theoryText: The discovery that Perona's real body is vulnerable while she projects her astral form follows the classic pattern of powerful abilities having hidden weaknesses. Her overconfidence in appearing invincible through intangibility directly leads to her downfall, as she doesn't adequately protect her physical body. This represents a common theme in One Piece where relying solely on Devil Fruit powers without proper strategy leads to defeat.
supportingEvidence: Episode 360 shows Perona's behavioral change when Kumashi is threatened
Usopp's observation skills allow him to deduce this weakness
The episode emphasizes that while her astral form is intangible, she cannot physically interact with the world
This follows the One Piece pattern of Devil Fruit powers having logical limitations

theoryText: The return of Sogeking at Thriller Bark represents more than just a disguise - it's Usopp's psychological mechanism for accessing courage he doesn't believe he naturally possesses. By 'becoming' Sogeking, Usopp can push past his fear and self-doubt to perform heroic actions. The episode shows this when facing certain defeat against Perona, Usopp 'calls upon' Sogeking to help him, essentially calling upon his own inner strength through this alter ego.
supportingEvidence: Sogeking first appeared during Enies Lobby when Usopp needed to help Robin despite being 'separated' from the crew
Episode 360 shows Usopp calling on Sogeking when he feels he cannot win alone
The mask serves as a physical representation of Usopp accessing his brave side
After defeating Kumashi, Usopp removes the mask showing he no longer needs it for that moment
counterEvidence: Some fans argue Sogeking is genuinely meant to be seen as a separate character within the narrative
The crew's reactions to Sogeking vary, with some seeming to not recognize him
